Title.evidence: Effect of Prophylactic Antibiotics on Intraoperative Cultures in Revision Arthroplasty: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: This multicenter, prospective randomised controlled trial was conducted at three centers, involving 65 patients

Participants.evidence: Eligibility required a culture-positive aspiration and no antibiotics within two weeks prior.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment, to receive prophylactic antibiotics either before skin incision or after obtaining a minimum of three sets of intraoperative cultures.

Objective.evidence: Administering prophylactic antibiotics before skin incision does not affect intraoperative culture results in revision arthroplasty.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the concordance of intraoperative and preoperative cultures, assessed immediately post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomised using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applicable due to the nature of the intervention.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Of the 65 randomised, 34 received antibiotics before incision, and 31 after culture collection.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Intraoperative cultures matched preoperative cultures in 28/34 (82%) of the pre-incision group and 25/31 (81%) of the post-culture group

Result_Outcome.evidence: Intraoperative cultures matched preoperative cultures in 28/34 (82%) of the pre-incision group and 25/31 (81%) of the post-culture group, demonstrating statistical equivalence (p = 0.0290).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group
